abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental management plan
            for the Rainfed Natural Resource Management Project for
            Mauritania, which improves basic ecological functions (water
            and mineral cycles, ecological succession) in order to
            sustainably increase yields in crops and livestock for
            participating communities. Expected negative impacts and
            measures to mitigate them fall into three categories:
            impacts from the process of soil rehabilitation, from
            production activities, and from hydraulic works. Impacts and
            mitigations include controlling new species and designating
            agricultural zones while planting trees and vegetation that
            could introduce parasitic diseases, increase competition for
            water resources, and lower agricultural production; using
            multiple sites instead of intensively exploiting a single
            site to reduce dust pollution; planting seedbeds and digging
            wells to avoid diminishing drinking water availability; and
            installing nurseries only in areas with sufficient resources
            to avoid diverting water from human and livestock use. Also
            included are strictly controlling areas to prevent wetlands
            from reducing water available for livestock and human
            consumption; regulating herd concentrations; and stressing
            agricultural extension and training and local production to
            avoid improper use and adaptation of farm machinery.
            Licensing water pumping will avoid pressures on the land
            arising from well digging and drilling; and managing
            underground dams will prevent water-borne diseases and desiccation.
